p: Among the biological species, marine algae are classified as one of the primitive producers of whole aquatic biomass making them a sources of natural bioactive molecules [ 43, 44, 45, 46]. Several functional metabolites derived from marine algae have shown health benefits [ 47]. The natural algal pigments (NPM) are often bioactive, particularly from Chlorophyceae, Rhodophyceae, and Phaeophyceae (or green, red, and brown algae, respectively) [ 43, 47]. The NPM synthesized by marine algae can be classified into three essential categories: carotenoids, chlorophylls, and phycobiliproteins [ 43]. Their stability is dependent on their chemical structures, which can be influenced by several factors, such as oxygen, light, heat, air, and pH [ 48]. The NPM are also characterized by their photosynthetic roles [ 47]. NMP have been applied in the food, nutraceuticals, and cosmetics industries [ 43] due to their antioxidant, antimicrobial, antidiabetic, antimalarial, anticancer, antiviral, anti-inflammatory, and anti-obesity activities ( Figure 2) [ 44, 49, 50].
